title: 109_s2443
content: The Act may be cited as the "Separate Enrollment and Line Item Veto Act of 2006" and outlines the structure of legislation. The "Separate Enrollment and Line Item Veto Act of 2006" requires detailed allocation information in appropriation measures, with a point of order if not met. Authorization legislation also mandates specific details in allocation. Authorization measures must present new direct spending or targeted tax benefits separately, with detailed allocation information. Failure to comply results in a point of order and recommittal to the committee. The conference report must contain detailed allocation information for appropriations and authorizations. Failure to comply with this requirement results in a point of order. If the House or Senate fails to comply with detailed allocation information in the conference report, it will not be allowed to consider the report. If a point of order is sustained, the measure will be sent back to the conference committee. SEC. 3. WAIVERS AND APPEALS. Any provision of section 2 may be waived or suspended in the House or Senate by an affirmative vote of three-fifths of the Members. An affirmative vote of three-fifths of the Members shall be required to sustain an appeal of the ruling of the Chair on a point of order. SEC. 4. SEPARATE ENROLLMENT. When an appropriation or authorization measure first passes both Houses of Congress in the same form, the items shall be disaggregated and assigned new bill numbers. Each item will be treated as a separate bill to be considered individually. The remaining parts of the bill will also be considered separately with the disaggregated bills. The bill must be disaggregated into separate bills without substantive revision, bearing the original designation and a new one if necessary. The new bills will be placed on the appropriate calendars in both Houses for consideration as the next order of business. The bills will be considered and voted on en bloc without amendment. Debate will be limited to 1 hour, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Further debate limitations or motions to recommit are not allowed. Reconsidering the vote on the bills is also not permitted. SEC. 5. VETO OF BILL. Amounts of budget authority, new direct spending, and revenues from a vetoed bill must be used for deficit reduction only. Committee allocations must be adjusted within 5 days after a veto override is no longer possible. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The title defines key terms related to appropriation and authorization measures, direct spending, and items in appropriations measures. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions under which a provision is considered an appropriation, including rescinding existing budget authority and limiting the President's spending authority. The curr_chunk defines a "targeted tax benefit" as a provision estimated to lose revenue for a specific period by the Joint Committee on Taxation. The curr_chunk discusses the criteria for a provision to be considered a "targeted tax benefit," which includes losing revenue for specific periods and providing favorable tax treatment to certain taxpayers. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW. Expedited Review allows any Member of Congress to challenge the constitutionality of a provision in the Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. The House of Congress has the right to intervene in such actions, which are heard by a three-judge court. This section ensures that the authority of the houses is not infringed upon. The House of Representatives and the Senate have the right to intervene in actions challenging the constitutionality of provisions in the Act. Any order issued by the US District Court for the District of Columbia can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court of the United States. No stay of the order can be issued by a single Justice of the Supreme Court. Expedited Consideration: The District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court must prioritize and speed up the resolution of any cases under this Act. Severability clause: If any part of the Act is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act remains unaffected.
